Question: FPP-001 - A flight plan has been filed for a flight departing at an uncontrolled aerodrome. When has the actual take-off time been transmitted to ATC?
Option D: At deviation from expected off-block time by more than 15 min.

Question: FPP-002 - During a flight with a flight plan submitted, landing is conducted at an airfield other than the destination stated in the filed flight plan. Who has to be contacted by the pilot immediately?
FPP-003 - Exceeding the maximum allowed aircraft mass is...
Option B: only relevant if the excess is more than 10 %.
Option C: compensated by the pilot's control inputs.

Question: FPP-004 - The center of gravity has to be located...
Option A: between the front and the rear C.G. limit.
Option C: in front of the front C.G. limit.
Option D: right of the lateral C. G. limit.
Answer: between the front and the rear C.G. limit.

Question: FPP-005 - The result of a rear C.G. position is...
FPP-006 - An aircraft must be loaded and operated in such a way that the center of gravity (CG) stays within the approved limits during all phases of flight. This is done to ensure...
Option A: that the aircraft does not exceed the maximum permissible airspeed during a descent.
Option B: that the aircraft does not stall.
Option C: that the aircraft does not tip over on its tail while it is being loaded.
Option D: both stability and controllability of the aircraft.
Answer: both stability and controllability of the aircraft.

Question: FPP-007 - The result of a front C.G. position is: 1. Increase in stability. 2. Increase in fuel consumption. 3. Increase in stall speed. 4. Increase in range.
FPP-008 - The basic empty mass of an aircraft includes...
Option A: the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding unusable fuel and traffic load. The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage.
Option B: the total mass of an aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation including the required fuel and crew, but excluding traffic load.
Option C: the mass of the aeroplane plus standard items such as unusable fuel and other unusable liquids, lubricating oil in engine and auxiliary units, fire extinguishers, pyrotechnics, emergency oxygen equipment, supplementary electronic equipment.
Option D: the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation including crew, navigation instruments and engine cowling.
Answer: the mass of the aeroplane plus standard items such as unusable fuel and other unusable liquids, lubricating oil in engine and auxiliary units, fire extinguishers, pyrotechnics, emergency oxygen equipment, supplementary electronic equipment.

Question: FPP-009 - The empty weight and the corresponding center of gravity (CG) of an aircraft are initially determined...
Option B: through data provided by the aircraft manufacturer.
Option D: for one aircraft of a type only, since all aircraft of the same type have the same mass and CG position.

Question: FPP-010 - The density of AVGAS 100LL at 15° C is...
FPP-011 - The conversion factor from kilogram [kg] into pounds [lb] is...
FPP-012 - Baggage and cargo must be properly stowed and fastened, otherwise a shift of the cargo may cause...
Option A: continuous attitudes which can be corrected by the pilot using the flight controls.
Option B: structural damage, angle of attack stability, velocity stability.
Option C: uncontrollable attitudes, structural damage, risk of injuries.
Option D: calculable instability if the C.G. is shifting by less than 10 %.
Answer: uncontrollable attitudes, structural damage, risk of injuries.

Question: FPP-013 - Loads must be adequately secured in order to...
Option C: avoid any centre of gravity (C.G.) movements.
Option D: prevent excessive 'g'-loading during the landing flare.
Answer: avoid any centre of gravity (C.G.) movements.

Question: FPP-014 - The total weight of an aeroplane is acting vertically through the...
FPP-015 - The term "center of gravity" is defined as...
Option A: the heaviest point on an aeroplane.
Option B: half the distance between the neutral point and the datum line.
Option C: another designation for the neutral point.
Option D: the point at which the total mass of the aeroplane is considered to act.
Answer: the point at which the total mass of the aeroplane is considered to act.

Question: FPP-016 - The center of gravity (CG) defines...
Option A: the point on the longitudinal axis or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
Option B: the point through which the force of gravity is said to act on a mass.
Option C: the distance from the datum to the position of a mass.
Option D: the product of mass and balance arm.
Answer: the point through which the force of gravity is said to act on a mass.

Question: FPP-017 - During an unaccelerated flight...
Option A: drag equals lift and thrust equals gravity.
Option B: thrust equals the sum of drag and gravity.
Option C: thrust equals lift and drag equals gravity.
Option D: thrust equals drag and lift equals gravity.
Answer: thrust equals drag and lift equals gravity.

Question: FPP-018 - The term "datum" with regard to a mass and balance calculation defines...
Option A: the point on the lateral axis of an aeroplane or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
Option B: the point on the vertical axis of an aeroplane or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
Option C: the point on the longitudinal axis of an aeroplane or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
Option D: the distance from the reference plane to the center of gravity of an aircraft.
Answer: the point on the longitudinal axis of an aeroplane or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.

Question: FPP-019 - The term "moment" with regard to a mass and balance calculation is referred to as...
Option A: sum of a mass and a balance arm.
Option B: quotient of a mass and a balance arm.
Option C: difference of a mass and a balance arm.
Option D: product of a mass and a balance arm.
Answer: product of a mass and a balance arm.

Question: FPP-020 - The term "balance arm" in the context of a mass and balance calculation defines the...
Option A: distance from the datum to the center of gravity of a mass.
Option B: distance of a mass from the center of gravity.
Option C: point on the longitudinal axis of an aeroplane or its extension from which the centers of gravity of all masses are referenced.
Option D: point through which the force of gravity is said to act on a mass.
Answer: distance from the datum to the center of gravity of a mass.

Question: FPP-021 - The distance between the center of gravity and the datum is called...
FPP-022 - The balance arm is the horizontal distance between...
Option A: the front C.G. limit and the datum line.
Option B: the C.G. of a mass and the rear C.G. limit.
Option C: the C.G. of a mass and the datum line.
Option D: the front C.G. limit and the rear C.G. limit.
Answer: the C.G. of a mass and the datum line.

Question: FPP-023 - The required data for a mass and balance calculation including masses and balance arms can be found in the...
Option A: performance section of the pilot's operating handbook of this particular aircraft.
Option B: mass and balance section of the pilot's operating handbook of this particular aircraft.
Answer: mass and balance section of the pilot's operating handbook of this particular aircraft.

Question: FPP-024 - When preparing to carry out the weighing procedure on an aircraft, which of the following is required?
FPP-025 - Which section of the flight manual describes the basic empty mass of an aircraft?

FPP-027 - What mass equals 102 litres of Avgas 100LL?

FPP-029 - Given values: Calculated take-off mass = 746 kg, calculated CG = 37.1 cm, fuel burn = 30.5 l on station 45 cm. Where is the CG situated after the landing?
FPP-030 - Calculated take-off mass = 1082 kg, calculated CG = 0.254 m, fuel burn = 55 l on station 0.40 m. Where is the CG situated after the landing?
FPP-031 - The position of the center of gravity (including fuel) equals...
FPP-032 - For the purpose of a flight preparation, the pilot calculates a total take-off mass of 750 kg and a total moment of 625 mmkg. Which cross marks the center of gravity (CG)?
FPP-033 - For the purpose of a flight preparation the pilot calculates a total take-off mass of 725 kg and a total moment of 650 mmkg. Which cross marks the center of gravity (CG)?
FPP-034 - For the purpose of a flight preparation the pilot calculates a total take-off mass of 775 kg and a total moment of 700 mmkg. Which cross marks the center of gravity (CG)?
FPP-035 - Which is the most recently determined empty mass and the associated center of gravity (CG) arm from the aircraft documentation?
FPP-036 - How does the aircraft configuration influence take-off performance while all other parameters remaining constant?
Option A: Aircraft B has a higher tyre pressure than aircraft A
Option B: Aircraft A has a higher tyre pressure than aircraft B
Option C: Aircraft B has a higher flap setting than aircraft A
Option D: Aircraft A has a higher flap setting than aircraft B
Answer: Aircraft A has a higher flap setting than aircraft B

Question: FPP-037 - How does aircraft flap configuration influence the take-off performance?
Option A: A higher flap setting decreases ground roll and increases lift-off speed and climb performance
Option B: A higher flap setting decreases ground roll and lift-off speed and increases climb performance
Option C: A higher flap setting increases ground roll, lift-off speed, and climb performance
Option D: A higher flap setting decreases ground roll and lift-off speed, but also climb performance
Answer: A higher flap setting decreases ground roll and lift-off speed, but also climb performance

Question: FPP-038 - How does wind affect the take-off performance?
Option A: Tailwind aids the aircraft in overcoming the initial drag at the commencement of the take-off roll. The take-off distance will decrease
Option B: Tailwind reduces the relative wind on the airfoil. The take-off distance will increase
Option C: Headwind causes an increased airflow around the wing. The take-off distance will increase
Option D: Headwind imposes an increased drag on the aircraft. The take-off distance will increase
Answer: Tailwind reduces the relative wind on the airfoil. The take-off distance will increase

Question: FPP-039 - It is possible that the surface wind speed at an airport is reduced due to friction. When a surface area with a minor tailwind condition is left during the initial climb, the pilot might expect...
Option A: an increase in airspeed and rate of climb due to decreasing tailwind.
Option B: a decrease in airspeed and climb performance due to decreasing tailwind.
Option C: an increase in airspeed and rate of climb due to increasing tailwind.
Option D: a decrease in airspeed and rate of climb due to increasing tailwind.
Answer: a decrease in airspeed and rate of climb due to increasing tailwind.

Question: FPP-040 - Which factor shortens landing distance?
FPP-041 - Unless the aircraft is equipped and certified accordingly...
Option A: flight into known or forecast icing conditions is only allowed as long as it is ensured that the aircraft can still be operated without performance degradation.
Option B: flight into forecast icing conditions is prohibited. Should the aircraft enter an area of icing conditions inadvertently, the flight may be continued as long as visual meteorological conditions are maintained.
Option C: flight into known or forecast icing conditions is prohibited. Should the aircraft enter an area of icing conditions inadvertently, it should be left without delay.
Option D: flight into areas of precipitation is prohibited.
Answer: flight into known or forecast icing conditions is prohibited. Should the aircraft enter an area of icing conditions inadvertently, it should be left without delay.

Question: FPP-042 - The speed Vx means...
Option A: that a given altitude is reached within minimum distance.
Option B: that a given altitude is reached within minimum flight time.
Option D: that a given altitude is reached with minimum fuel consumption.
Answer: that a given altitude is reached within minimum distance.

Question: FPP-043 - The angle of descent is defined as...
Option A: the ratio between the change in height and the horizontal distance travelled within the same time, expressed in percent [%].
Option B: the angle between a horizontal plane and the actual flight path, expressed in degrees [°].
Option C: the ratio between the change in height and the horizontal distance travelled within the same time, expressed in degrees [°].
Option D: the angle between a horizontal plane and the actual flight path, expressed in percent [%].
Answer: the angle between a horizontal plane and the actual flight path, expressed in degrees [°].

Question: FPP-044 - The term "steady flight" is defined as...
Option A: flight with a steady power setting without changing course.
Option B: climb or descent with a constant climb or descent rate in calm weather conditions.
Option C: unaccelerated flight. The four forces thrust, drag, lift, and weight are in equilibrium.
Option D: flight in smooth air without turbulence and a perfectly trimmed aircraft.
Answer: unaccelerated flight. The four forces thrust, drag, lift, and weight are in equilibrium.

Question: FPP-045 - The speed Vy is defined as...
FPP-046 - The speed VFE is defined as...
Option A: stalling or minimum steady flight speed with the flaps retracted.
Option C: stalling or minimum steady flight speed with the flaps extended.

Question: FPP-047 - The speed VS0 is defined as...
Option B: stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed obtained in a specific configuration.
Option C: stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in landing configuration.
Answer: stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in landing configuration.

Question: FPP-048 - The beginning of the green arc (2) indicates which airspeed?
Option A: VS1: Stall speed with flaps up
Option B: VS0: Stall speed in landing configuration
Option D: VNO: Maximum speed for normal operations
Answer: VS1: Stall speed with flaps up

Question: FPP-049 - The end of the green arc (4) indicates which airspeed?
Option A: VNO: Maximum speed for normal operations
Option D: VS1: Stall speed with flaps up
Answer: VNO: Maximum speed for normal operations

Question: FPP-050 - The red marking at the end of the yellow arc (5) indicates which airspeed?
Option A: VNO: Maximum speed for normal operations
Option C: VS1: Stall speed with flaps up

Question: FPP-051 - Which climb speed may be used to optimize the rate of climb (e.g. to reach a desired altitude within minimum time)?
Option A: Vy, the best angle of climb speed
Option B: Vy, the best rate of climb speed
Option C: Vx, the best rate of climb speed
Option D: Vx, the best angle of climb speed
Answer: Vy, the best rate of climb speed

Question: FPP-052 - For a take-off from runway 22 and a reported wind of 250°/10 kt, the longitudinal wind component equals...
FPP-053 - Given the following conditions, the take-off distance equals... Outside air temperature: -20° C, Pressure Altitude: 5000 ft, Aeroplane mass: 750 kg, Headwind: 10 kt
FPP-054 - A pilot wants to take off on runway 36, the reported wind is 240 degrees, 12 knots. What is the value of the wind components acting on the aircraft on take-off and landing?
Option A: Crosswind from the right 10.4 kt., Tailwind 6 kt.
Option B: Crosswind from the left 10.4 kt., Tailwind 6 kt.
Option C: Crosswind from the left 6 kt., Tailwind 10.4 kt.
Option D: Crosswind from the right 6 kt., Headwind 10.4 kt.
Answer: Crosswind from the left, 10.4 kt., Tailwind 6 kt.

Question: FPP-055 - What is the take-off distance at 750 kg take-off mass, standard (ISA) conditions at an elevation of 4000 ft with 5 kt tailwind?

FPP-057 - A pilot wants to take off on runway 36, the reported wind is 240 degrees 12 knots. What are the wind components acting on the aircraft on take-off and landing?
Option A: Crosswind from the right 10.4 kt., Tailwind 6 kt.
Option B: Crosswind from the right 6 kt., Headwind 10.4 kt.
Option C: Crosswind from the left 10.4 kt., Tailwind 6 kt.
Option D: Crosswind from the left 6 kt., Tailwind 10.4 kt.
Answer: Crosswind from the left, 10.4 kt., Tailwind 6 kt.

FPP-073 - The term "maximum elevation figure" (MEF) is defined as...
Option A: the highest elevation within an area covering 30 minutes of latitude and 30 minutes of longitude.
Option B: the highest elevation within an area covering 30 minutes of latitude and 30 minutes of longitude plus a safety margin, rounded to the next higher 100 ft.
Option C: the highest elevation within an area covering 30 minutes of latitude and 30 minutes of longitude plus a safety margin of 1000 ft (305 m), rounded to the next higher 100 ft.
Option D: the highest elevation within an area covering 1 degree of latitude and 1 degree of longitude plus a safety margin, rounded to the next lower 100 ft.
Answer: the highest elevation within an area covering 30 minutes of latitude and 30 minutes of longitude plus a safety margin, rounded to the next higher 100 ft.

Question: FPP-074 - What is the purpose of "interception lines" in visual navigation?
Option A: To visualize the range limitation from the departure aerodrome
Option B: They help to continue the flight when flight visibility drops below a VFR minima
Option C: To mark a the next point available in the -route en route during flight
Option D: They are used to intercept recognizable guidance upon a possible loss of landing
Answer: They are used to recognizable landing as easy guidance after a possible loss of landing

FPP-097 - Given the following data for a VFR flight:
Trip fuel = 70 US gallons
Contingency fuel = 5% of trip fuel
Alternate and final reserve fuel = 20 US gallons
Usable fuel at take-off = 95 US gallons
After half of the distance you read that you have consumed 40 US gallons.
Assume that fuel flow remains unchanged.
Which statement is correct?
Option A: Upon landing 15.0 US gallons will remain in addition to alternate and final reserve fuel.
Option B: Upon landing 5.0 US gallons will remain in addition to alternate and final reserve fuel.
Option C: Upon landing, a total of 40.0 US gallons will remain.
Option D:
The remaining fuel is insufficient for a landing at destination with alternate and final reserve fuel
remaining.
Answer:
The remaining fuel is insufficient for a landing at destination with alternate and final reserve fuel
remaining.

Question:
FPP-098 - Given the following data for a VFR flight:
Trip fuel = 70 US gallons
Contingency fuel = 5% of trip fuel.
Alternate and final reserve fuel = 20 US gallons
Usable fuel at take-off = 90 US gallons
After half of the distance you read that you have consumed 30 US gallons.
Assume that fuel flow remains unchanged.
Which statement is correct?
Option A: The remaining fuel is insufficient for a landing at destination with alternate and final reserve fuel remaining.
Option B: Upon landing 30.0 US gallons will remain in addition to alternate and final reserve fuel.
Option C: Upon landing 10.0 US gallons will remain in addition to alternate and final reserve fuel.
Option D: Upon landing a total of 10.0 US gallons will remain
Answer: Upon landing 10.0 US gallons will remain in addition to alternate and final reserve fuel.

FPP-102 - How does the air temperature influence the performance of a piston engine?
Option A: Lower temperature corresponds to higher air density,this leads to lower engine performance
Option B: Higher temperature corresponds to lower air density,this leads to lower engine performance
Option C: Higher temperature corresponds to higher air density,this leads to higher motor performance
Option D: Lower temperature corresponds to lower air density,this leads to higher motor performance
Answer: Higher temperature corresponds to lower air density,this leads to lower engine performance
